title: Whenever a talk radio show occasionally plays a song, for whatever reason, do they have to pay the artist, even if they only play a small clip of it? - Quora

response.answer_text: They don’t pay the artist directly. A radio station buys a license from an organization like BMI or ASCAP. Music Users | BMI.com For that fee, the station and its programs can play the songs that org represents and the org uses the fee money they collect to pay the artists (the composers and song writers). How does the org know what every program on every radio station has played so that they pay each artist the right amount of money? That is controversial, but that is another story.

Not typically. Most all US radio stations have licenses with Ascap, BMI, Sesac, etc (music publishers and licensing agencies). The talk radio stations licenses are for “limited use”…(for just bumper songs, occasional airplay or snippets of music) and therefore are NOT paid for by the national syndicated talent or it’s syndication firms.
